I'm Vicki MacDonald and I'm in Holy Trinity Church, Llandudno, as part of the Longest Yarn.
And I'm now going to speak to Nigel Morgan because he's going to tell me a story about his father during the war.
Thank you, Nigel. Thank you very much indeed.
Not a problem at all, Vicki. Nice to meet you.
I'm just showing Vicki a photograph of my dad, which was taken in Dieppe, in France, not long after D-Day, after they landed.
So, this is my dad, Hugh Morgan.
He was 19 years old when he made the unimaginable journey from his roots in Blenifest-Inyog to the battlefields in France on D-Day June 1944,
with his band of brothers that were the RASC, the Royal Army Service Corps.
I remember him telling me stories of when him and some of his mates were in a bomb crater moving forward towards the enemy lines.
At one point in the battle, him and some of his friends advanced the next crater.
And as they jumped for safety into the next muddle, the one he had just left was hit with a mortar round,
killing all his friends that just a few short minutes before he had been alongside, he counted himself very lucky.
He never called himself a hero, but he was always a hero to me.
In fact, I'm just having his medals re-ribboned by James Malins, who's a local Army Cadet captain,
and they're going to be completed by the end of this month.
In fact, I've just only just picked them up.

realized he was part of the RASC, had a quick look at trying to do some research into where they fitted into everything.
I looked on the Imperial War Museum and I found the actual, the RASC were part of the landing party.
They were part of, normally, they're part of D-Day landings, which I never really knew before.
So it was new to me and it was a huge honor.
And I'm very disappointed that over the years, I never got to speak to my dad more about this.
I wish I'd have known.
But in order to pay homage to my dad, I've now got his medals re-ribboned.
And this year, I'm hoping to be able to honor my father's memory and his service by wearing his medals proudly on Remembrance Day.
